document_title: Rat poison poisoning: Symptoms, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
Rat poison poisoning is a condition in which the poison of rat poison affects the target organs (nervous, cardiovascular, kidney, respiratory, hematological, digestive, skin, etc.) or has a toxic effect (causing cancer, mutation, organ damage, etc.). (first)
Neurological: Headache, fatigue, dizziness, irritation, irritability, struggling, hallucinations, eventually convulsions, coma, dilated pupils.; Cardiovascular: Rapid pulse, low blood pressure, arrhythmia.; Acute kidney failure: Due to shock, tubular necrosis, rhabdomyolysis.; Respiratory: Feeling of tightness in the chest, cough, difficulty breathing, cyanosis, acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (myocardial damage, acute heart failure), non-cardiac acute pulmonary edema (damage to blood vessels, lung damage due to phosphine gas ) or both, ARDS, pulmonary hemorrhage.; Hematology: hemolysis (may occur even in people with normal G6PD), may see methemoglobin.; Gastrointestinal: Patients have burning pain in the mouth, throat, esophagus, and stomach; Vomiting and vomiting blood, loose and possibly bloody stools.; Skin and mucous membranes: Toxins that come into contact through the skin and mucous membranes can cause local irritation.
Rat poison poisoning, if not treated promptly, can lead to death
subsection_title: ngo doc thuoc diet chuot.json. What is rat poison poisoning?
